questions.text: A 35 years old female came to dermatology OPD with complaints of multiple pruritic follicular keratotic and spinous papules all over the body and scarring alopecia of the scalp for 4 years. On examination, dilated follicular orifices plugged with keratotic debris were seen with marked perifollicular violaceous hyperpigmentation and complete loss of hair. Axillary and pubic hair were sparse with a history of recurrent episodic shedding for the last 3 years. Histopathological examination shows marked hypergranulosis along with the presence of vacuolar degeneration and apoptotic keratinocytes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Graham Little Piccardi Lasseur Syndrome
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Graham Little Piccardi Lasseur Syndrome The given clinical history is suggestive of Graham Little Piccardi Lasseur Syndrome. Graham Little–Piccardi–Lassueur: a rare variant of lichen planopilaris , an inflammatory form of scarring hair loss. Most commonly affects middle-aged postmenopausal women. It comprises the triad : multifocal scalp cicatricial alopecia non-scarring alopecia of the axillae and/or groin keratotic lichenoid follicular papules Treatment: Topical and oral corticosteroids Retinoids (acitretin) PUVA Ciclosporin Thalidomide

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- < Option B. Christ-siemens-Touraine syndrome: Characterized by abnormal development of ectodermal derived tissue like hair, nail, and teeth with decreased function of sweat gland. Option C. Clouston’s syndrome: It is a group of 150 conditions characterized by abnormal development of some or all structures of ectodermal origin including skin, hair, nails, teeth and sweat glands. Option D. Rothmund-Thomson syndrome: Rare genetic disorder characterized by distinctive abnormalities of the skin, sparse hair, eyelashes and/or eyebrows, small stature, and skeletal and dental abnormalities with increased risk of osteosarcoma.

questions.text: A previously healthy 46-year-old woman comes to her physician because of an itchy rash on her legs. She denies any recent trauma, insect bites, or travel. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the oral cavity shows white lace-like lines on the buccal mucosa. A photograph of the rash is shown. A biopsy specimen of the skin lesion is most likely to show which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased thickness of the stratum granulosum

options.label: C
options.text: The proliferation of atypical squamous cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Lymphocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction Lichen planus is a chronic (T-cell mediated) inflammatory disease and may present with cutaneous , oral , and/or genital lesions . The classical lesions of cutaneous lichen planus are described as 6 P’s: Polygonal, pruritic, planar (flat-topped), purple, papules and plaques. Site: Flexural (in contrast to psoriasis) Koebner’s phenomenon seen (New lesions appear on sites of trauma ) Prognosis: heals spontaneously with hyperpigmentation over 1-2 years Histopathological findings : Hyperkeratosis Sawtooth lymphocytic infiltration at Dermal-epidermal junction Civatte's (Colloid) bodies Wedge-shaped hypergranulosis Irregular acanthosis Treatment: Limited disease- topical steroids Widespread disease- oral steroids Steroid sparing agent- Methotrexate, Dapsone Risk factors: Physical and emotional stress Systemic infections like hepatitis C Localized infections like herpes zoster Drugs: gold, quinine Physical and emotional stress

Highyeild:

Important findings in lichen planus Mucosa: Painless, white, lacy pattern streaks - Wickham striae Painful and persistent ulcers (Erosive LP: rare, premalignant potential) Desquamative gingivitis Inflammation near amalgam fillings (trigger factor) Nail Changes: Dorsal Nail Pterygium ( Most specific) Irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges with thinning of the nail plate (Most common) Pup-tent sign Subungual hyperkeratosis Permanent destruction of nails Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy Hair: Scarring alopecia ( Lichen planopilaris ) - Destruction of hair follicles leading to permanent bald patches. Treatment- Topical steroids are the mainstay. Other- intralesional, systemic steroids, PUVA therapy, Cyclosporine, Dapsone, Tacrolimus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- < Option A. Decreased thickness of the stratum granulosum: It is a feature of psoriasis. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silver scales. Option B. Inflammation of subcutaneous adipose tissue: It is seen in panniculitis Option C. The proliferation of atypical squamous cells: It would suggest the possibility of squamous cell carcinoma, which is not consistent with the patient's clinical presentation.

Extraedge:

Pseudopelade of Brocq- Variant of lichen planus with scarring alopecia and no inflammation or scaling which appears like ‘ footprints in the snow’

questions.text: A male presented with dark, very itchy, non-scaly, dry plaques on lower legs as shown. The lesions have been present since 8 years and seems to be enlarging. What is the likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen planus The given clinical scenario is of Lichen Sclerosus. Aka lichen Sclerosus et atrophicus, kraurosis vulvae (in females) & balanitis xerotica obliterans (in males) It is a chronic inflammatory skin disease which mainly affects the perianal and the genital region. More common in Women than males Can occur at any age but is more common in over 50 years of age . Positive family history Often present with co-existing skin conditions like psoriasis, lichen simplex, erosive lichen planus, vitiligo, or morphea. History of other autoimmune conditions present like alopecia areata, pernicious anaemia or thyroid disorders. Clinical features: Pale, Ivory or white patches (hyperkeratosis and sclerosis) and nodules are found in the anogenital region that can coalesce to form plaques. (crinkling or cellophane paper–type appearance) “Figure-of-eight” distribution around vulva and anus, with purpura/ecchymosis, hyperkeratosis and sclerosis is seen. Increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma Management: First, a Biopsy is done to rule out neoplastic changes. The lesions can be treated with highly potent topical steroids such as clobetasol . Patients who have not been circumcised should be advised to undergo circumcision. Meatoplasty in severe cases with scarring of the Urethral meatus.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Eczema typically presents with red, itchy, and scaly patches. While chronic eczema can lead to darkening (hyperpigmentation) of the skin. Option B. Tinea is a fungal infection that causes ringworm. It usually presents with a red, itchy, circular rash with well-defined borders and central clearing. Option C. Psoriasis can cause red, itchy, and scaly plaques.

questions.text: A patient presented with scarring alopecia, thinned nails, hyperpigmented macular lesions over the trunk. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen planus Scarring alopecia, thin nails and hyperpigmented skin lesions point to a diagnosis of lichen planus.

Highyeild:

Lichen planus word is derived from leichen , “tree moss” and planus —“flat”. 5P’s—Purple (violaceous), Polygonal, Pruritic, Plane topped (flat), Papules On the surface, white criss-cross streaks (Wickham striae) are seen especially, if a thin layer of oil is applied to the surface—classical feature Flexural predisposition (Contrast to psoriasis which has extensor distribution) Koebner’s phenomenon Usually self-limiting within 1 or 2 years and heals leaving hyperpigmentation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Psoriasis will have red skin lesions with scaling. There is no scarring alopecia. Nails will be thick Option B- Lupus erythematosus will have scarring alopecia but with scales (carpet tac scales). Lesions are only on sun exposed areas and will be red, scaly and atrophic Option D- Pemphigus will have bullae

questions.text: The isomorphic phenomenon is seen in all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen sclerosus It is a chronic inflammatory skin disease which mainly affects the perianal and the genital region. It doesn’t show koebner’s phenomenon. -Koebner's phenomenon or Isomorphic phenomenon : New and similar lesions of the original disease developing at sites of trauma (scratches, surgical incisions, & injury) and indicate active disease It is seen in: Psoriasis Lichen planus Vitiligo

questions.text: ”Claw clutching ball” pattern is characteristic of?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen nitidus Lichen nitidus is an inflammatory skin disease which presents as localized, tiny, skin-coloured bumps in children involving the flexor aspects of the forearm, backs of hands, penis, chest, abdomen and buttocks. Can also involve the face . It is commonly seen in preschool and school-aged children or young adults. Can affect either of the sexes and occurs in all races. Common association : Lichen planus Down syndrome Crohn's disease Atopic dermatitis HIV infection Congenital megacolon Juvenile chronic arthritis Histopathological findings: Discrete lymphohistiocytic infiltrate expanding 1 - 4 dermal papillae Epidermal collarette gives the classic ball and claw appearance (90% of cases) Multinucleated giant cells (foreign body or Touton-type ) often present Overlying hyperkeratosis with or without parakeratosis is seen. Basal layer vacuolation and colloid bodies may be prominent

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Lichen planus: Skin lesions are seen as plain purple polygonal pruritic papules, with lymphocytic infiltration on supra dermal layer on histology. Option C. Psoriasis: It is a papulosquamous disorder which consists of an erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling over the extensors. Option D. Amyloidosis: Group of diseases with abnormal proteins i.e amyloid fibrils, built up in tissue.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with the following presentation as in the image. He says that he did have an itchy red rash affecting the wrists, arms, and legs, but this disappeared after about 6 months. Other sites affected by this disorder include all except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Extensors of body The given image showing the loss of the nail plate and formation of dorsal nail pterygium with a history of itchy, red rash is suggestive of Lichen Planus. Lichen planus is a chronic (T-cell mediated) inflammatory disease and may present with cutaneous , oral , and /or genital lesions . Often associated with hepatitis C. It commonly affects the Flexors more than the extensors. The lesions are distributed along the lines of Blaschko (Represents the pathway of epidermal cell migration during the embryological stage of development) Nails are involved in 10% of the cases.

Highyeild:

Important findings in lichen planus Mucosa: Painless, white, lacy pattern streaks - Wickham striae Painful and persistent ulcers (Erosive LP: rare, premalignant potential) Desquamative gingivitis Inflammation near amalgam fillings (trigger factor) Nail Changes: Dorsal Nail Pterygium ( Most specific) Irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges with thinning of the nail plate (Most common) Pup-tent sign Subungual hyperkeratosis Permanent destruction of nails Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy Hair: Scarring alopecia ( Lichen planopilaris ) - Destruction of hair follicles leading to permanent bald patches.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, & D. It affects the anogenital region, baccalaureate mucosa and tongue and scalp.

questions.text: A male presents with dark red and mauvish papules and nodules on the legs that are extremely itchy. They have been present for 8 months and seem to be enlarging. The patient is worried and in discomfort. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lichen planus The given image of hypertrophic, pink/purple plaques with peripheral hyperpigmentation over the lower extremity is suggestive of Hypertrophic lichen planus. This usually develops during the course of a subacute attack, but occasionally only hypertrophic or warty lesions are found. They most often occur on the lower limbs , especially around the ankles ; venous stasis has been put forward as an explanation. The development of hypertrophic lesions greatly lengthens the course of the disease, as they may persist for many years. The lesions heal with areas of pigmentation, scarring and some degree of atrophy.

Highyeild:

Important findings in lichen planus Mucosa: Painless, white, lacy pattern streaks - Wickham striae Painful and persistent ulcers (Erosive LP: rare, premalignant potential) Desquamative gingivitis Inflammation near amalgam fillings (trigger factor) Nail Changes: Dorsal Nail Pterygium ( Most specific) Irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges with thinning of the nail plate (Most common) Pup-tent sign Subungual hyperkeratosis Permanent destruction of nails Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy Hair: Scarring alopecia ( Lichen planopilaris ) - Destruction of hair follicles leading to permanent bald patches.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Eczema or Atopic dermatitis (AD) or eczema is a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin condition which typically affects the face, neck, arms, and legs but usually spares the groin and axillary area. Associated with elevated IgE and patients often have a history of asthma. Option B. Prurigo nodularis is a chronic skin disease character poised by the presence of hard, extremely itchy bumps which under histopathology can show thick, orthohyperkeratosis, irregular epidermal hyperplasia, and pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia. Option C. Psoriasis is a papulosquamous disorder which consists of an erythematous plaque with silvery white scaling over the extensors. Histology shows parakeratosis, absence of stratum granulosum, acanthosis, dermal T cell infiltration, tortuous and dilated dermal vessels and enlarged dermal papillae.

Extraedge:

questions.text: All are histology features of lichen planus except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epidermal neutrophils Epidermal neutrophilic collection is a feature of psoriasis and not LP.

Highyeild:

Histology of LP Basal epidermal cell destruction Clefts at dermoepidermal junction, probably an artifact (Max-Joseph spaces) Liquefaction of the basal layer Hypergranulosis Necrotic/apoptotic keratinocytes are called as colloid bodies, cytoid bodies or civatte bodies Basal melanocytes may also fall down into the dermis (pigment will be seen in the upper dermis—called pigment incontinence) Band of lymphocytes + Basal cell destruction/vacuolization = Interface dermatitis
